questions.text: A 68-year-old female with a history of multiple sclerosis has been using a urinary catheter for the past two months. Recently, she developed symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI), including dysuria and fever. Urine culture was performed to identify the causative organism. What is the most common causative organism of catheter-induced urinary tract infections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) E. coli

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Klebsiella: Although Klebsiella is a known UTI pathogen, it is less common compared to E. coli in catheter-associated UTIs.
  • • Option B. Klebsiella:
  • • known UTI pathogen,
  • • less common compared to E. coli
  • • Option C . Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas is more commonly associated with hospital-acquired infections and in patients with compromised immune systems, but not the most common in catheter-induced UTI.
  • • Option C
  • • Pseudomonas:
  • • more commonly associated with hospital-acquired infections
  • • Option D. Staphylococcus: It is more commonly associated with skin and soft tissue infections rather than UTIs.
  • • Option D. Staphylococcus:
  • • associated with skin and soft tissue infections

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with symptoms of dysuria, frequency, and urgency. She has no significant past medical history and her urine culture reveals Escherichia coli sensitive to multiple antibiotics. She has no known drug allergies. Based on her presentation and culture results, which of the following would be the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Norfloxacin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Meropenem: This is a carbapenem antibiotic usually reserved for hospital-acquired UTIs or infections caused by multidrug-resistant gram-negative bacilli. It is not indicated in this case due to its broad spectrum and the risk of promoting antibiotic resistance.
  • • Option A. Meropenem:
  • • carbapenem antibiotic
  • • reserved for hospital-acquired UTIs
  • • infections caused by multidrug-resistant gram-negative bacilli.
  • • Option C. Piperacillin-Tazobactam: This is a beta-lactam-beta-lactamase inhibitor combination used for serious hospital-acquired infections and is an over-treatment for a simple community-acquired UTI.
  • • Option C. Piperacillin-Tazobactam:
  • • beta-lactam-beta-lactamase inhibitor combination used for serious hospital-acquired infections
  • • Option D. Fosfomycin: Although effective for uncomplicated UTIs , it is not the first choice when other more standard treatments, like quinolones, are available and the organism is susceptible.
  • • Option D. Fosfomycin:
  • • effective for uncomplicated UTIs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For uncomplicated community acquired UTIs , antibiotics like quinolones (e.g., Norfloxacin) are preferred when the organism is sensitive . Reserve higher antibiotics such as carbapenems and beta-lactam-beta-lactamase inhibitor combinations for hospital-acquired UTIs or infections with multidrug-resistant organisms. It's important to choose antibiotics judiciously to avoid over-treatment and the development of antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with a two-day history of burning sensation during urination and a white urethral discharge. He admits to having unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners.   • • inguinal lymphadenopathy

  • • causative agent of syphilis
  • • painless chancre in primary syphilis
  • • Option D. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Although a common cause of urethritis, it usually shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci on Gram stain , which was not seen in this case.

  • • D. Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
  • • common cause of urethritis,
  • • gram-negative intracellular diplococci
  • • Gram stain

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a genital ulcer. He reports the ulcer appeared about two weeks ago and describes it as moderately painful. questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Option A. Syphilis: Typically presents with a painless, indurated, single ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy. This does not match the patient's symptoms of a painful ulcer and painful lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option A. Syphilis:
  • • painless, indurated, single ulcer
  • • painless lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option B. Herpes: Herpes genitalis usually presents with multiple, painful ulcers . However, the marked lymphadenopathy described in this patient is more consistent with chancroid.
  • • Option B. Herpes:
  • • presents with multiple, painful ulcers
  • • Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, LGV can present with genital ulcers but is more characterized by painful and soft lymphadenopathy , which can be similar to chancroid . However, the nature of the ulcer in LGV (single or multiple) and the longer incubation period make chancroid more likely in this case.
  • • Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):
  • • Chlamydia trachomatis, LGV can present with genital ulcers but is more characterized by painful and soft lymphadenopathy
  • • chancroid

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a 3-day history of fever, irritability, and tugging at his right ear. The child had a cold one week ago, which seemed to improve but then worsened with the current symptoms. On examination, the tympanic membrane of the right ear is red and bulging. There is no discharge or foul smell noted. What is the most likely causative agent of this child's ear infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pneumoniae

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of fever, dyspnea, and a non-productive cough. He recently attended a crowded international conference. Chest X-ray reveals a widened mediastinum and bilateral infiltrates. The patient rapidly progresses to severe respiratory distress. A history of similar cases among other conference attendees is reported. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis (Anthrax)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Variola major (Smallpox) - Typically presents with fever and a characteristic rash , not primarily with respiratory symptoms.

  • • Option C. Yersinia pestis (Plague) - While it can cause pneumonic plague , it is less likely in this scenario given the rapid progression and specific radiological findings.

  • • cause pneumonic plague
  • • less likely
  • • Option D. Francisella tularensis (Tularemia) - Can cause pneumonic tularemia but is less likely than anthrax to present with a widened mediastinum and rapid progression in a bioterrorism scenario.
